sections.summary: This opening range describes the Scripture as having verses that are perfected and elaborated by the Wise and Informed. It commands humanity to worship none but **Allah** and emphasizes that seeking **forgiveness** and **repentance** leads to good sustenance and divine grace.

Allah is established as the Knower of all secrets and the provider of **sustenance** for every moving creature on earth. The text explains that life is a **test** of conduct and critiques the human tendency to oscillate between **despair** and **pride** depending on their experience of mercy or adversity [163–164].

sections.theme: Truth of Revelation versus Worldly Desires
sections.summary: In response to skeptics, Allah challenges the production of ten fabricated chapters and affirms that the Quran is revealed with **divine knowledge**. It warns that those who prioritize the **worldly life** will have their deeds nullified in the Hereafter, contrasting them with the believers who **humble** themselves before their Lord [164–165].

Noah warns his people of a painful Day, but the elite reject him as a mere mortal and a liar. The account details the construction of the **Ark**, the drowning of the defiant—including Noah’s son—and the eventual receding of the **Flood** on Mount Judi, serving as a lesson in **patience** for the pious [165–168].

sections.theme: Hud and the People of Aad
sections.summary: Hud calls the people of Aad to worship **Allah** and seek forgiveness to gain strength, but they accuse him of being possessed by their gods. Consequently, the community is pursued by a **curse** and destroyed for their stubborn tyranny, while Hud and the believers are saved by **mercy** [168–169].

sections.theme: Saleh and the People of Thamood
sections.summary: Saleh exhorts Thamood to recognize Allah as their Originator and provides a **she-camel** as a divine sign. After the people hamstrung the camel in defiance, they were struck by a **Scream** that left them lifeless, illustrating the consequences of rejecting **prophetic guidance**.

Divine messengers visit Abraham to grant him good news of the birth of **Isaac** and **Jacob**. Despite Abraham’s gentle nature and his pleading for the people of Lot, he is informed that the **decree** of his Lord for their destruction has become irreversible [169–170].

Lot is grieved by his people’s demand to commit **lewdness** with his guests, who reveal themselves as angels sent to execute judgment. The cities are destroyed at dawn by being turned upside down and bombarded with **stones of baked clay** marked by Allah [170–171].

sections.theme: Shuaib and the People of Median
sections.summary: Shuaib enjoins his community to give full **measure and weight** and to desist from corruption. Their ridicule of his faith and reliance on their own tribal strength ends in their annihilation by a **Blast**, mirroring the total removal of Thamood [171–172].

Moses is sent with a **clear mandate** to Pharaoh, whose followers are led into the Fire for obeying a misguided tyrant. These historical reports serve as an **encompassing sign** of the severe grip of Allah upon sinful towns and the certainty of the Day of Account [172–173].

The surah concludes with a command to remain **upright** and to establish **prayer**, noting that good deeds remove evil ones. It affirms that the history of the messengers strengthens the heart and that all authority belongs to Allah, necessitating total **worship** and **reliance** on Him [173–174].
